lessonOverview.title: Unit 2 - Lesson 1
structures: B: It’s on the 8th of February.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name the twelve months of the year when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Display the months on the board. Say them aloud as students repeat. Then play “Find the Month” – point and say the wrong word for students to correct.
stretchStrategies: Students create a “Birthday Calendar Wall” by writing their birthdays on sticky notes and arranging them by month, then ask 2–3 classmates about their birthdays.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about dates using “What’s the date today?” and “When is your birthday?” and respond with “It’s the... of...” / “It’s on the... of...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Pair activity: Students take turns asking “When is your birthday?” and answering with “It’s on the 10th of July.” Use birthday flashcards for support.
stretchStrategies: Students create a “Birthday Calendar Wall” by writing their birthdays on sticky notes and arranging them by month, then ask 2–3 classmates about their birthdays.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structures “What’s the date today? It’s the ___ of ___.” and “When is your birthday? It’s on the ___ of ___.” to talk about dates.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write model Q&A frames on board: “What’s the date today? – It’s the ___ of ___.” Students complete with today’s date and practise in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Students create a “Birthday Calendar Wall” by writing their birthdays on sticky notes and arranging them by month, then ask 2–3 classmates about their birthdays.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
